docs.title: KubeHatch - Minimalistic Internal Kubernetes platform
docs.text: KubeHatch simplifies creating virtual Kubernetes clusters (vClusters) dynamically using a user-friendly web UI, automating deployment and management tasks.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This CLI helps you easily create and manage isolated ephemeral Kubernetes clusters (vClusters) for quick and efficient testing, validation, and automation scenarios. You can provide your own kubeconfig or rely on a default kubeconfig of the cluster on which the CLI is running.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Create isolated Kubernetes clusters (vClusters).
  • Optional High Availability (HA) setup.
  • Uses user-provided or default kubeconfig.
  • Automated exposure of vClusters via LoadBalancer services.
  • Complete self-hosted web UI.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Kubernetes Cluster
  • Helm CLI
  • vCluster CLI

docs.title: 1. Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/LoftLabs-Experiments/kubehatch.git
cd kubehatch

docs.title: Step 2: Build and Push Docker Image
docs.text:
Ensure you're logged in to your container registry (e.g., Docker Hub).

docker build -t yourdockerusername/kubehatch-backend -f Dockerfile.backend .
docker push your-container-registry/your-image-name:latest

Replace your-container-registry with your registry and image name.

docs.title: Step 3: Deploy to Kubernetes
docs.text:
Backend Deployment

Apply Kubernetes manifests:

kubectl apply -f backenddeploy.yaml
kubectl apply -f backendsvc.yaml

docs.title: Step 3: Configure Frontend and Ingress
docs.text:
Edit your ingress.yaml to point to the correct backend service. Then apply it:

kubectl apply -f ingress.yaml

Ensure your domain points to your ingress controller IP.

docs.title: Step 4: Using the UI
docs.text:
Open your UI hosted via ingress in your browser:

http://<your-ingress-domain>

docs.title: Using KubeHatch
docs.text:
Create vCluster with custom kubeconfig

  • Open the UI.
  • Enter a vCluster name.
  • Optional: Select kubeconfig file (if not provided, the default cluster kubeconfig is used).
  • Click Create.
  • Wait for vCluster creation to complete. Your generated kubeconfig will appear, and you can download it for use.

docs.title: Create vCluster without custom kubeconfig
docs.text: Simply provide a name and click Create. The system will automatically use the default kubeconfig from the cluster.

docs.title: Cleanup
docs.text:
Delete virtual clusters manually using:

vcluster delete <cluster-name> -n vcluster-<cluster-name>

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
Verify RBAC permissions are correctly set.

Check logs:

kubectl logs deploy/vcluster-backend

Enjoy creating ephemeral Kubernetes environments seamlessly with KubeHatch!

docs.title: 🛠️ Building KubeHatch Locally
docs.text: This guide will walk you through setting up and building the KubeHatch CLI from source.

docs.title: 📌 Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before you start, ensure you have the following installed:

  • Go (1.22 or later) → Download Go
  • Git (for cloning the repository) → Install Git
  • A Kubernetes cluster (for testing, optional)
  • Kubectl & Helm (optional, for cluster interaction)

docs.title: 🚀 Step 1: Clone the Repository
docs.text:
First, clone the repository from GitHub:

git clone https://github.com/LoftLabs-Experiments/kubehatch.git
cd kubehatch

docs.title: ⚙️ Step 2: Install Dependencies
docs.text:
Navigate to the backend/ directory and fetch the required Go modules:

cd backend
go mod github.com/YOUR-USERNAME/kubehatch
go mod tidy

🏗️ Step 3: Build the KubeHatch CLI Run the following command inside the backend/ directory to compile the binary:

go build -o kubehatch main.go

This will generate an executable named kubehatch inside the backend/ directory.

docs.title: Step 4: Verify Installation
docs.text:
Check if the CLI is built correctly by running:

./kubehatch

You should see the available commands and usage.

docs.title: 📝 Additional Notes
docs.text:
If you make changes to dependencies, always run go mod tidy before building.

To cross-compile for different operating systems, use:

GOOS=linux GOARCH=amd64 go build -o kubehatch-linux main.go

🎉 Congratulations! You have successfully built the KubeHatch CLI from source. 🚀

For further details, visit the Quickstart Guide.

docs.title: 🚀 Quickstart Guide: Deploying KubeHatch on Kubernetes
docs.text: This guide walks you through deploying KubeHatch on a Kubernetes cluster.

docs.title: 🛠 Prerequisites
docs.text: Ensure you have the following tools installed before proceeding: - kubectl - Helm - Access to a Kubernetes cluster - (Optional) Kustomize if using overlays

docs.title: 🔐 Step 1: Create Kubernetes Secret for Authentication and default Kubeconfig
docs.text:
Before deploying, create a Kubernetes Secret to store sensitive credentials.

kubectl create secret generic vcluster-basic-auth  --from-literal=username=admin  --from-literal=password=password
kubectl create secret generic vcluster-default-kubeconfig --from-file=kubeconfig=/root/.kube/config -n default

NOTE - Make sure to replace the path of your kubeconfig file.

docs.title: Build the Frontend and backend Images
🚀 Step 2: Deploy the frontend and backend manifests
docs.text: Replace the backedna dn frontend deployment with the images you created and then deploy the manifest from the k8s folder.

docs.title: Deploy ingress nginx controller
docs.text: kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/controller-v1.9.4/deploy/static/provider/cloud/deploy.yaml

docs.title: Quickstart
docs.text:
🏗 Step 3: Deploy Using Helm (Alternative) If you prefer Helm, add the Helm repository and install KubeHatch:

sh Copy Edit helm repo add kubehatch https://loftlabs-experiments.github.io/kubehatch/ helm repo update helm install kubehatch kubehatch/kubehatch -n kubehatch --create-namespace Verify the deployment:

sh Copy Edit kubectl get deployments -n kubehatch 🔍 Step 4: Access the KubeHatch Service To access the service locally, use kubectl port-forward:

sh Copy Edit kubectl port-forward svc/kubehatch-service 8080:80 -n kubehatch Then, visit http://localhost:8080 in your browser.

🎯 Next Steps Check logs: kubectl logs -f deployment/kubehatch -n kubehatch Expose externally with an Ingress: sh Copy Edit kubectl apply -f ingress.yaml Read the Build from Source Guide for local development. ✅ Done! 🎉 You have successfully deployed KubeHatch on Kubernetes.
